body:
Problem: The hide option for floating windows was not respected in some window detection functions, causing them to improperly include hidden floating windows.

Solution: Added checks for the hide property in w_config to ensure hidden floating windows are properly ignored in relevant detection functions.

Fix #30503

comment_regular_data.body:
Is there such a thing as a focusable "hidden" window? If not, then can we set `focusable=false` when `hide` is set (why is it not called `visible`?!)? Then we don't need to check both.

What does it mean for a window to be hidden but focusable? Is that something that makes sense and should be supported?



I started some docs updates for `:windo` and CTRL-W in https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/30510 to call out "focusable" behavior.
Oh, otherwise another check is needed in `win_close()` as well.

root of the problem should be what you @justinmk said. Focusable has no meaning for the hide window, maybe? Because it is invisible, the cursor cannot be focused on this window. It should be checked and an error should be thrown when parsing config.

Maybe not. In the initial case I'd hide it. Record the hide state. Re-show the window when needed. It could be focusable so I'd only have to record one state. Although I can make the focusable value negate the hide. But I need to set two fields.
We need both fields, but the question is, in the code updated in this PR (and similar), why would this code need to check `hide`? When would a window have `hide=true` and `focusable=true` ?

> In the initial case I'd hide it. Record the hide state. Re-show the window when needed. 

initial case create a hide float window first . when some condition is triggered it will be shown by `hide=true`  `focusable` can only set in initial case . because it is hidden it will not be focusable even if focusable is true. Plugin authors do not need to worry about whether certain fields can be set at the same time.

> because it is hidden it will not be focusable even if focusable is true.

Show a Lua code sample where this happens. When and how can `focusable=true` AND `hide=true`, and why do we need to support that?

If a plugin sets `focusable=true` on a `hide=true` window, then either (1) Nvim should raise an error, or (2) Nvim should set `hide=false`. 

The question is whether this situation *makes sense*. If it doesn't make sense then we should do one of the above, and then *internally* we don't need to check `(!wp->w_config.hide && wp->w_config.focusable)` everywhere (that makes no sense), we only need to check `focusable`.
A plugin usually only changes one field in `nvim_win_set_config`, in which case the other fields remain unchanged.

> A plugin usually only changes one field in `nvim_win_set_config`, in which case the other fields remain unchanged.

But I am suggesting that if a plugin calls `nvim_win_set_config(..., {focusable=true})`, that should automatically also set `hide=false`. Alternatively, I am asking why we shouldn't do that--what is the use-case for `hide=true && focusable=true` ?

If a plugin (or internal Nvim code) checks `if (focusable)`, the result should not be a lie. Is a *hidden* window *focusable*? What happens when `nvim_set_current_win()` is called on a hidden, non-focusable window?

> But I am suggesting that if a plugin calls `nvim_win_set_config(..., {focusable=true})`, that should automatically also set `hide=false`.

If `nvim_win_set_config(..., {hide=true})` then `focusable` would be automatically set to `false`?

Later doing`nvim_win_set_config(..., {hide=false})`, what happens to `focusable`?

Maybe `nvim_win_set_config` only allow hide to be set to `true` and ... Never mind, it gets crazy.

-----

PS: As mentioned elsewhere: hide is an action, hidden is a state (and I prefer visible). Can it be changed?

Mentioning this here because there is a similar problem coming up regarding interacting window flags.

The recently opened #30490 and #30504 can be solved by the addition of a window config flag [mousable](https://wiktionary.org/wiki/mouseable). `mousable` has a similar relationship with `focusable` as `hide`. 

In `nvim_win_open` if `mousable` is not explicitly set, it should be set to the the value of `focusable`. If `focusable` and/or `hide` are changed, and `mousable` is not explicitly changed as well, what should happen? #30504 will have evolving notes on this.

Should it be tracked if an option/flag is, or has been, explicitly set?

Curiously before logging in this morning I was planning to ask if there are any guidelines and/or macros for handling interacting options/flags. Guess the jury is still out.

Emulates something like emacs and helix showing diagnostics in the top right corner. I can do this to allow jumping to pasted diagnostic information. Because it won't be focused when hidden. I only need to change hide when showing it. Rather than changing focusable and hide.

```lua
-- just example
api = vim.api
vim.cmd[[ au! DiagnosticChanged ]]
local bufnr = api.nvim_create_buf(false, false)
local win = api.nvim_open_win(bufnr, false, {
  relative = 'editor',
  row = 1,
  col = vim.o.columns - 20,
  height = 20,
  width = 20,
  focusable = true,
  hide = true,
})
vim.api.nvim_create_autocmd('DiagnosticChanged', {
  callback = function()
    local d = vim.tbl_map(function(o) return o.message:gsub('\n', '') end, vim.diagnostic.get())
    if not vim.tbl_isempty(d) then
      api.nvim_buf_set_lines(bufnr, 0, -1, false, d)
      return api.nvim_win_set_config(win, { hide = false })
    end
    api.nvim_win_set_config(win, { hide = true })
  end,
})
```

After some experimentation using the patch. Works good with my simple UI usage.

There's an issue about having a visible cursor in a non-focused area. IMHO, it doesn't seem priority. Maybe it should be considered a separate issue.

The following might be considered an artificial situation. It's still possible to enter hidden, focusable windows through scripts (or command line). Even though, in general, a script shouldn't leave the focus in a hidden/focusable window, there's some behavior I'm seeing that might be considered a bug.


Here's a mapping used with the problem code from #30503
```
vim.keymap.set('n', 'Z2', function() vim.api.nvim_set_current_win(popup_wid) end)
```

2. `:sou` creating the hidden focusable window
